title: Tesla deserves credit for avoiding the electric car scrapheap
text:
Tesla’s first electric vehicle, released 11 years ago, was not exactly a brand new car.

The fledgling start-up, as it then was, built its Roadster around a chassis ordered from Lotus, rather than beginning from scratch. Features such as the windshield, steering wheel and rear-view mirrors - around 7pc of the total parts - were shared with the British carmaker.

There were clear advantages to this: it meant Elon Musk’s project to change the face of the car industry did not have to start from scratch, and using already-approved parts meant some of the safety hurdles that it would have otherwise encountered were cleared.

Tesla had a contract for just 2,500 Lotus shells, which it took four years...
